column17: and because the probation officer had substantial reason to believe that respondent's answers were likely to be incriminating.

column1: Held:  The Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments did not prohibit the introduction into evidence of respondent's admissions to the probation officer in respondent's subsequent murder prosecution.  Pp. 426-440.
(a) The general obligation to appear before his probation officer and answer questions truthfully did not
column2: in itself
column3: convert respondent's otherwise voluntary statements into compelled ones.  Pp.  465 U. S. 427-429.

column1: (b) A witness confronted with questions that the government should reasonably expect to elicit incriminating evidence ordinarily must assert the Fifth Amendment privilege
column2: rather than answer if he desires not to incriminate himself.  If he chooses to answer rather than to assert the privilege
column3: his choice is considered to be voluntary
column4: since he was free to claim the privilege and would suffer no penalty as a result of his decision to do so.  P.  465 U. S. 429.

column1: (c) Respondent cannot claim the benefit of the ""in custody"" exception to the general rule that the Fifth Amendment privilege is not self-executing.
It is clear that respondent was not ""in custody"" for purposes of receiving Miranda protection
column2: since there was no formal arrest or restraint on freedom of movement of the degree associated with formal arrest.  The factors that the probation officer could compel respondent's attendance and truthful answers and consciously sought incriminating evidence
column3: that respondent did not expect questions about prior criminal conduct and could not seek counsel before attending the meeting
column4: and that there were no observers to guard against abuse or trickery
column5: neither alone nor in combination
column6: are sufficient to excuse respondent's failure to claim the privilege in a timely manner.  Pp.  465 U. S. 429-434.

column1: (d) Nor was respondent deterred from claiming the privilege against self-incrimination by a reasonably perceived threat of revocation of his probation so as to render the privilege self-executing.  The legal compulsion to attend the meeting with the probation officer and to answer truthfully the questions of the officer who anticipated incriminating answers is indistinguishable from that felt by any witness who is required to appear and give testimony
column2: and is insufficient to excuse respondent's failure to exercise the privilege in a timely manner.  Whether a subjective or objective test is applied
column3: there is no reasonable basis for concluding that Minnesota attempted to attach an impermissible penalty to the exercise of the privilege.  Pp.  465 U. S. 434-439.

column1: (e) As opposed to the cases involving federal taxes on gamblers
column2: where the Fifth Amendment privilege may be exercised by failing to file a tax return
column3: since
column4: if the taxpayer claimed the privilege instead of filing a return
column5: he necessarily identifies himself as a gambler
column6: a probationer confronted with incriminating questions ordinarily would have no problem effectively claiming the privilege at the time the disclosures are requested.  There is therefore no reason to forgive the requirement that the privilege claim be presented for evaluation in a timely manner.  Pp.  465 U. S. 439-440.

column1: The city of Peoria received federal block grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 (HCDA)
column2: which provides for such grants for urban renewal programs.  As authorized by the HCDA
column3: the city designated a community-based
column4: social service corporation to be the city's subgrantee in charge of the administration of the federal grants.  Petitioners
column5: officers responsible for the expenditure of the federal funds and administration of the corporation's urban renewal programs
column6: were indicted for violating the federal bribery statute
column8: by using their positions to extract kickbacks from contractors seeking to work on housing rehabilitation projects.  Before trial
column9: the Federal District Court denied petitioners' motions to dismiss the indictment on the asserted ground that they were not ""public officials"" under 18 U.S.C.  201(a)
column10: which defines the term ""public official"" as including

column1: an officer or employee or person acting for or on behalf of the United States
column2: or any department
column3: agency or branch of Government thereof
column5: under or by authority of any such department
column6: agency
column7: or branch of Government.""

column2: and the Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  Petitioners are ""public officials"" within the meaning of  201(a)
column2: and thus are subject to prosecution under the bribery statute.  Pp.  465 U. S. 489-501.

column1: (a) There is no merit in petitioners' contention that they cannot be considered to be persons ""acting for or on behalf of the United States"" under the statutory definition
column2: because neither they nor their employer ever entered into any direct agreement with the Federal Government.  Although the language of  201(a) does not decide the dispute
column3: its legislative history -- including Congress' longstanding commitment to a broadly drafted federal bribery statute
column4: its desire to continue that tradition when it adopted the language of  201(a) in the 1962 revisions of the federal conflicts of interest and bribery statutes
column5: and its awareness of the federal judiciary's interpretation of the identical phrase in earlier federal bribery statutes to have a broad jurisdictional reach (particularly the Second Circuit's

column1: decision in United States v. Levine
column2: 129 F.2d 745) -- establishes that Congress never intended  201(a)'s open-ended definition of ""public official"" to be restricted to persons in a formal employment or agency relationship with the Government.  The proper inquiry is whether the person occupies a position of public trust with official federal responsibilities.  Pp.  465 U. S. 489-496.

column1: (b) Given the structure of the HCDA program and petitioners' responsible positions as administrators of the subgrant
column2: they served as public officials for purposes of  201(a).  In allocating the federal resources made available to the city through the HCDA grant program
column3: petitioners were charged with abiding by federal guidelines
column4: which dictated both where and how the federal funds could be distributed.  By accepting the responsibility for distributing the federal resources
column5: petitioners assumed the quintessentially official role of administering a social service program established by Congress.  Pp.  465 U. S. 496-498.

column1: (c) The majority of recent decisions in lower federal courts supports the conclusion that employment by the United States or some other similarly formal contractual or agency bond is not a prerequisite to prosecution under the federal bribery statute.  Pp.  465 U. S. 498-499.

column2: or that all employees of local organizations responsible for administering federal grant programs are public officials within the meaning of  201(a).  To be a public official under the statute
column3: an individual must possess some degree of official responsibility for carrying out a federal program or policy.  Pp.  465 U. S. 499-501.

The Minnesota Public Employment Labor Relations Act (PELRA) authorizes state employees to bargain collectively over terms and conditions of employment.  The statute also grants professional employees
column2: such as college faculty
column3: the right to ""meet and confer"" with their employers on matters related to employment that are outside the scope of mandatory bargaining.  However
column4: if professional employees forming an appropriate bargaining unit have selected an exclusive representative for mandatory bargaining
column5: their employer may ""meet and confer"" on nonmandatory subjects only with that representative.  Appellant Minnesota State Board for Community Colleges (Board) operates the Minnesota community college system
column6: and appellant Minnesota Community College Faculty Association (MCCFA) is the designated exclusive representative of the faculty of the State's community colleges.  On the state level
column7: MCCFA and the Board established ""meet and confer"" committees to discuss policy questions applicable to the entire system.  On the campus level
column8: the MCCFA chapters and the college administrations created local ""meet and confer"" committees to discuss policy questions applicable only to the campus.  Appellees
column9: 20 Minnesota community college faculty instructors who are not members of MCCFA
column10: filed suit in Federal District Court

column13: the constitutionality of MCCFA's exclusive representation of community college faculty in the ""meet and confer"" processes. column14: and the court granted declaratory and injunctive relief.

Before the voir dire examination of prospective jurors began at a trial in California Superior Court for the rape and murder of a teenage girl
column2: petitioner moved that the voir dire be open to the public and the press.  The State opposed the motion
column3: arguing that
column5: juror responses would lack the candor necessary to assure a fair trial.  The trial judge agreed and permitted petitioner to attend the ""general"" but not the ""individual"" voir dire proceedings.  All but approximately three days of the 6-week voir dire was thus closed to the public.  After the jury was empaneled
column6: petitioner moved for release of the complete transcript of the voir dire proceedings
column7: but both defense counsel and the prosecutor argued that release of the transcript would violate the jurors' right to privacy.  The court denied the motion and
column8: after the defendant had been convicted and sentenced to death

column1: 1. The guarantees of open public proceedings in criminal trials cover proceedings for the voir dire examination of potential jurors.  Pp.  464 U. S. 505-510.

(a) The historical evidence reveals that the process of selection of jurors has presumptively been a public process with exceptions only for good cause shown.  The presumptive openness of the jury selection process in England carried over into proceedings in colonial America
column2: and public jury selection was the common practice in America when the Constitution was adopted.  Pp.  464 U. S. 505-508.

column1: (b) Openness enhances both the basic fairness of the criminal trial and the appearance of fairness so essential to public confidence in the criminal justice system.  Public proceedings vindicate the concerns of the victims and the community in knowing that offenders are being brought to account for their criminal conduct by jurors fairly and openly selected.  Closed proceedings
column2: although not absolutely precluded
column3: must be rare
column4: and only for cause shown that outweighs the value of openness.

column1: The presumption of openness may be overcome only by an overriding interest based on findings that closure is essential to preserve higher values and is narrowly tailored to serve that interest.  Pp.  464 U. S. 508-510.

2. The presumption of openness has not been rebutted in this case.  There were no findings to support the trial court's conclusion that an open proceeding would threaten the defendant's right to a fair trial and the prospective jurors' interests in privacy.  Even with findings adequate to support closure
column2: the court's orders denying access to the voir dire transcript failed to consider whether alternatives were available to protect the prospective jurors' interests.  To preserve fairness and at the same time protect legitimate privacy
column3: a trial judge should inform the prospective jurors
column4: once the general nature of sensitive questions is made known to them
column5: that those individuals believing public questioning will prove damaging because of embarrassment may properly request an opportunity to present the problem to the judge in camera but with counsel present and on the record.  When limited closure is ordered
column6: the constitutional values sought to be protected by holding open proceedings may be satisfied later by making a transcript of the closed proceedings available within a reasonable time
column7: if the judge determines that disclosure can be accomplished while safeguarding the juror's valid privacy interests.  Even then a valid privacy interest may rise to a level that part of the transcript should be sealed
column8: or the name of a juror withheld
column9: to protect the person from embarrassment.  Pp.  464 U. S. 510-513.

column1: Respondent parents and son sued petitioner in Federal District Court to recover damages sustained by the son when his feet came in contact with the blades of a riding lawnmower manufactured by petitioner.  After a trial that extended over a 3-week period
column2: the District Court entered judgment for petitioner upon a jury verdict and denied respondents' motion for a new trial.  One of the grounds alleged for a new trial was that the District Court had erred in denying respondents' motion to approach the jury after the judgment was entered because one of the jurors had not responded to a question on voir dire seeking to elicit information about previous ""injuries . . . that resulted in any disability or prolonged pain or suffering"" to members of the juror's immediate family when
column3: in fact
column4: the juror's son had sustained a broken leg as a result of an exploding tire.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column5: holding that the juror's failure to respond affirmatively to the question on voir dire had prejudiced respondents' right of peremptory challenge.

column1: Held:  Respondents are not entitled to a new trial unless the juror's failure to disclose denied them their right to an impartial jury.  Courts should exercise judgment in preference to the automatic reversal for ""error"" and ignore errors that do not affect the essential fairness of a trial.  To invalidate the result of a 3-week trial because of a juror's mistaken
column2: though honest
column3: response to a question
column4: is to insist on something closer to perfection than our judicial system can be expected to give.  It ill-serves the important end of finality to wipe the slate clean simply to recreate the peremptory challenge process because counsel lacked an item of information that he should have obtained from a juror on voir dire examination.  The Court of Appeals' standard is contrary to the practical necessities of judicial management reflected in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 61 and the harmless error statute
column5: 28 U.S.C.  2111.  To obtain a new trial in such a situation
column6: a party must first demonstrate that a juror failed to answer honestly a material question on voir dire
column7: and then further show that a correct response would have provided a valid basis for a challenge for cause.  Pp.  464 U. S. 553-556.

column1: Respondent parents and son sued petitioner in Federal District Court to recover damages sustained by the son when his feet came in contact with the blades of a riding lawnmower manufactured by petitioner.  After a trial that extended over a 3-week period
column2: the District Court entered judgment for petitioner upon a jury verdict and denied respondents' motion for a new trial.  One of the grounds alleged for a new trial was that the District Court had erred in denying respondents' motion to approach the jury after the judgment was entered because one of the jurors had not responded to a question on voir dire seeking to elicit information about previous ""injuries . . . that resulted in any disability or prolonged pain or suffering"" to members of the juror's immediate family when
column3: in fact
column4: the juror's son had sustained a broken leg as a result of an exploding tire.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column5: holding that the juror's failure to respond affirmatively to the question on voir dire had prejudiced respondents' right of peremptory challenge.

column1: Held:  Respondents are not entitled to a new trial unless the juror's failure to disclose denied them their right to an impartial jury.  Courts should exercise judgment in preference to the automatic reversal for ""error"" and ignore errors that do not affect the essential fairness of a trial.  To invalidate the result of a 3-week trial because of a juror's mistaken
column2: though honest
column3: response to a question
column4: is to insist on something closer to perfection than our judicial system can be expected to give.  It ill-serves the important end of finality to wipe the slate clean simply to recreate the peremptory challenge process because counsel lacked an item of information that he should have obtained from a juror on voir dire examination.  The Court of Appeals' standard is contrary to the practical necessities of judicial management reflected in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 61 and the harmless error statute
column5: 28 U.S.C.  2111.  To obtain a new trial in such a situation
column6: a party must first demonstrate that a juror failed to answer honestly a material question on voir dire
column7: and then further show that a correct response would have provided a valid basis for a challenge for cause.  Pp.  464 U. S. 553-556.

Neither is there anything in the wording of  6501(a) that itself enables a taxpayer to reinstate the section's general 3-year limitations period by filing an amended return.  Moreover
column3: the substantive operation of the fraud provisions of the Code itself confirms the conclusion that  6501(c)(1) permits assessment at any time in fraud cases regardless of a taxpayer's later repentance.  Pp.  464 U. S. 391-396.

column1: (c) There is no need to twist  6501(c)(1) beyond the contours of its plain and unambiguous language in order to comport with good policy
column2: for its literal language is supported by substantial policy considerations -- the increased difficulty in investigating fraud cases as opposed to cases marked for routine audits; the fact that the filing of a document styled ""amended return"" does not fundamentally change the nature of a tax fraud investigation; and the compounding of the difficulties that attend a civil fraud investigation where the Commissioner's initial findings lead him to conclude that the case should be referred to the Department of Justice for criminal prosecution. column3: in a case of failure to file a return
column4: the tax may be assessed ""at any time"" -- has been construed as ceasing to apply once a return has been filed for a particular year
column5: regardless of whether that return is filed late and even though the failure to file a timely return in the first instance was due to fraud.  However
column6: the language employed in the respective subsections of  6501 establishes that Congress intended different limitations results under  6501(c)(1).  Pp.  464 U. S. 400-401.

column4: alleging that VTR consumers had been recording some of respondents' copyrighted works that had been exhibited on commercially sponsored television
column5: and thereby infringed respondents' copyrights
column6: and further that petitioners were liable for such copyright infringement because of their marketing of the VTR's.  Respondents sought money damages
column7: an equitable accounting of profits
column8: and an injunction against the manufacture and marketing of the VTR's.  The District Court denied respondents all relief
column9: holding that noncommercial home use recording of material broadcast over the public airwaves was a fair use of copyrighted works
column10: and did not constitute copyright infringement
column11: and that petitioners could not be held liable as contributory infringers even if the home use of a VTR was considered an infringing use.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column12: holding petitioners liable for contributory infringement and ordering the District Court to fashion appropriate relief

(a) The protection given to copyrights is wholly statutory
column2: and

column4: in which Congress has not plainly marked the course to be followed by the judiciary
column5: this Court must be circumspect in construing the scope of rights created by a statute that never contemplated such a calculus of interests.  Any individual may reproduce a copyrighted work for a ""fair use""; the copyright owner does not possess the exclusive right to such a use.  Pp.  464 U. S. 428-434.

This case does not fall in the category of those in which it is manifestly just to

column2: the only contact between petitioners and the users of the VTR's occurred at the moment of sale.  And there is no precedent for imposing vicarious liability on the theory that petitioners sold the VTR's with constructive knowledge that their customers might use the equipment to make unauthorized copies of copyrighted material.  The sale of copying equipment
column3: like the sale of other articles of commerce
column4: does not constitute contributory infringement if the product is widely used for legitimate
column5: unobjectionable purposes
column6: or
column7: indeed
column8: is merely capable of substantial noninfringing uses.  Pp.  464 U. S. 434-442.

column2: recorded at a time when the VTR owner cannot view the broadcast so that it can be watched at a later time); and (2) that there is no likelihood that time-shifting would cause nonminimal harm to the potential market for
column3: or the value of
column4: respondents' copyrighted works.  The VTR's are therefore capable of substantial noninfringing uses.  Private
column5: noncommercial time-shifting in the home satisfies this standard of noninfringing uses both because respondents have no right to prevent other copyright holders from authorizing such time-shifting for their programs and because the District Court's findings reveal that even the unauthorized home time-shifting of respondents' programs is legitimate fair use. column2: see Pacific Gas & Electric Co. v. State Energy Resources Conservation and Development Comm'n
column4: does not extend to the state-authorized award of punitive damages for conduct related to radiation hazards.  There is ample evidence that Congress had no intention
column5: when it enacted and later amended the Atomic Energy Act of 1954
column6: of forbidding the States to provide remedies for those suffering injuries from radiation in a nuclear plant.  Nor is appellee able to point to anything in the legislative history of the Price-Anderson Act -- which established an indemnification scheme for operators of nuclear facilities -- or in the implementing regulations that indicates that punitive damages were not to be allowed. column7: it is clear

column3: Congress assumed that state law remedies were available to those injured by nuclear incidents

column3: a team of arson investigators arrived at the residence for the first time to investigate the cause of the blaze. column4: the investigators entered the residence and conducted an extensive search without obtaining either consent or an administrative warrant.  Their search began in the basement
column5: where they found two Coleman fuel cans and a crock pot attached to an electrical timer.  The investigators determined that the fire had been caused by the crock pot and timer and had been set deliberately.  After seizing and marking the evidence found in the basement

Section 307(c)(1) of the Coastal Zone Management Act (CZMA) provides that
[e]ach Federal agency conducting or supporting activities directly affecting the coastal zone shall conduct or support those activities in a manner which is
column2: to the maximum extent practicable
column3: consistent with approved state management programs.""

column1: CZMA defines the ""coastal zone"" to include state but not federal land near the shorelines of the several coastal States
column2: as well as coastal waters extending ""seaward to the outer limit of the United States territorial sea.""  The territorial sea for the States bordering on the Pacific Ocean or Atlantic Ocean extends three geographical miles seaward from the coastline.  Submerged lands subject to the jurisdiction of the United States that lie beyond the territorial sea constitute the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS).  By virtue of the Submerged Lands Act
column3: the coastal zone belongs to the States
column4: while the OCS belongs to the Federal Government.  In these cases
column5: the Department of the Interior (Interior)
column6: rejecting California's demands that a consistency review was required under  307(c)(1)
column7: sold oil and gas leases of certain tracts on the OCS off the coast of California.  California and other interested parties then filed suits in Federal District Court to enjoin the sale of some of the tracts
column8: alleging that Interior had violated  307(c)(1) in that leasing sets in motion a chain of events that culminates in oil and gas development and therefore ""directly affects"" the coastal zone within the meaning of  307(c)(1).  The District Court entered a summary judgment for the plaintiffs
column9: holding that a consistency determination was required before the sale.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  Interior's sale of OCS oil and gas leases is not an activity ""directly affecting"" the coastal zone within the meaning of  307(c)(1)
column2: and thus a consistency review is not required under that section before such sales are made.  Pp.  464 U. S. 320-343.

column1: (a) CZMA nowhere defines or explains which federal activity should be viewed as ""directly affecting"" the coastal zone
column2: but the legislative history of  307(c)(1) discloses that Congress did not intend the section to reach OCS lease sales.  The ""directly affecting"" language was aimed primarily at activities conducted or supported by federal agencies on federal lands physically situated in the coastal zone but excluded from the zone as formally defined by CZMA.  This reading of  307(c)(1) finds further support in the history of other sections of CZMA.  Pp.  464 U. S. 321-330.

column1: (b) Nor is a broader reading of  307(c)(1) compelled by the thrust of other CZMA provisions.  It is clear that Congress believed that CZMA's purposes could be adequately effectuated without reaching federal activities conducted outside the coastal zone.  Moreover
column2: an examination of  307's structure suggests that lease sales are a type of federal agency activity not intended to be covered by  307(c)(1).  Section 307(c)(3)
column3: which deals with private parties' activities authorized by a federal agency's issuance of licenses and permits
column4: is the provision that is more pertinent to OCS lease sales
column5: and that provision definitely does not require consistency review of such sales.  Pp.  464 U. S. 331-335.

column2: ""produce
column3: or ""develop"" oil or gas.  By the time the leases in question here were sold

column5: or production from"" the lease tracts.  Since 1978
column6: when the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act of 1953 (OCSLA) was amended
column7: there have been four statutory stages to developing an offshore oil well:  (1) preparation of a leasing program
column8: (2) lease sales (the stage in dispute here)
column9: (3) exploration by the lessees
column10: and (4) development and production.  The purchase of an OCS lease
column11: standing alone
column12: entails no right to explore for
column14: or produce oil or gas resources on the OCS.  The first two stages are not subject to consistency review
column15: but the last two stages are.  Under OCSLA's plain language
column16: the purchase of a lease entails no right to proceed with full exploration
column18: or production that might trigger  307(c)(3)(B)'s consistency review provisions; the lessee acquires only a priority in submitting plans to conduct those activities.  Pp.  464 U. S. 335-341.

column4: and does not authorize full-scale exploration

column1: (a) Under the doctrine of collateral estoppel
column2: once a court has decided an issue of fact or law necessary to its judgment

column7: and does not apply against the Government.  Pp.  464 U. S. 158-159.

column6: and would require substantial revision of the Solicitor General's policy for determining when to appeal an adverse decision
column7: a policy that involves consideration of a variety of factors

column1: Held:  The doctrine of mutual defensive collateral estoppel is applicable against the Government to preclude relitigation of the same issue already litigated against the same party in another case involving virtually identical facts.  Cf. Montana v. United States

(a) The doctrine of collateral estoppel generally applies to preclude relitigation of both issues of law and issues of fact if those issues were conclusively determined in a prior action involving the same parties.  The exception to the applicability of the principles of collateral estoppel for ""unmixed questions of law"" arising in ""successive actions involving unrelated subject matter
column2: Montana v. United States
column3: supra
column5: does not apply here.  Whatever the purpose or extent of the exception

column1: there is no reason to apply it here to allow the Government to litigate twice with the same party an issue arising in both cases from virtually identical facts.  Pp.  464 U. S. 169-172.

(b) Nor is an exception to the doctrine of mutual defensive estoppel justified here on the asserted ground that its application in Government litigation involving recurring issues of public importance will freeze the development of the law. column2: it still leaves EPA free to litigate the same issue in the future with other litigants.  Pp.  464 U. S. 173-174.

may suspend deportation plainly narrows the class of aliens who may obtain suspension. column1: Held:  Section 613A was not intended to deny the allowance for percentage depletion on advance royalty or lease bonus income altogether; rather
column2: 611-613A entitle taxpayers to such an allowance at some time during the productive life of the lease.  Pp.  464 U. S. 214-227.

column1: (a) Any reasonable interpretation of  613A must harmonize with the section's goal of subsidizing the combined efforts of small producers and royalty owners in the exploration and production of the Nation's oil and gas resources.  The Commissioner's interpretation -- under which taxpayers would receive percentage depletion on income derived from oil and gas interests only if the payment associated with that income could be attributed directly to specific units of production
column2: and which anomalously suggests that a Congress intent on increasing domestic production by small producers included substantial economic disincentives in the same legislation -- does not comport with this goal.  By contrast
column3: allowing percentage depletion on all qualified income makes available the maximum public subsidy that Congress was willing to provide.  Pp.  464 U. S. 217-220.

column1: (b) The legislative history of  613A discloses a clear congressional intent to retain the percentage depletion rules that existed in 1975
column2: and under which taxpayers leasing their interests in mineral deposits were entitled to a percentage depletion on any bonus or advance royalty whether there was production of the underlying mineral or not.  Pp.  464 U. S. 220-223.

column1: (c) When  613A is considered together with related Code sections and in light of the legislative history
column2: it is clear that Congress did not mean to withdraw the percentage depletion on lease bonuses or advance royalty income arising from oil and gas properties.  Section 613A clearly provides that income attributable to production over a certain level will not be eligible for percentage depletion
column3: but nothing in the statute bars such a depletion on income received prior to actual production.  To the contrary
column4: so long as the income can be attributed to production below the established ceilings
column5: lease bonuses and royalty income come within the four corners of the percentage depletion provisions.  Pp.  464 U. S. 223-224.

column1: (d) Since the Commissioner's interpretation is unreasonable
column2: this Court will not defer to it.  The Commissioner has not shown any ""insurmountable"" practical problems that would render his position more tenable.  While  613A's various production requirements and limitations make accurate calculation of percentage depletion allowances difficult

column3: as
column5: by requiring lessors to defer depletion deductions to years of actual production or to adjust deductions taken with amended returns.  The Commissioner cannot resolve the practical problems by eliminating the allowances altogether.  Pp.  464 U. S. 224-227.

column2: (c) prohibits federal courts from considering federal habeas corpus petitions that contain specific allegations of error that are integral to the constitutional challenge but were not raised in the state courts.
